title: 103_hr3679
content: The Act titled "Junior Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program Act of 1994" establishes a program. The "Junior Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program" established by the Secretary of the Interior aims to provide environmental education opportunities for school children regarding migratory bird conservation and to enhance conservation and education programs in schools, States, and other educational programs. The Program includes conducting activities in interested States and other authorized activities. The Secretary of the Interior's "Junior Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program" includes conducting activities in all 50 states and submitting an annual report to Congress on the program's status in each state. The Junior Duck Stamp program is established under SEC. 3. The Secretary may conduct an annual competition for students to submit designs related to bird conservation. Winning designs can be licensed and marketed as Junior Duck Stamps. Proceeds from licensing and marketing will be available to the Secretary for conservation purposes. The appropriations are for awards and scholarships for winning designs in competitions, education activities related to conservation goals, and expenses for licensing and marketing. Administrative expenses are not allowed. The Secretary is authorized to accept gifts, devises, or bequests of personal property to fund activities described in section 3(c)(1) (A) and (B). Authorization of appropriations is also granted. The Secretary may transfer the Cusano bequest to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation for environmental education purposes at the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge. The Foundation must match the bequest with non-Federal contributions and manage the funds accordingly. The Cusano bequest, totaling approximately $2,473,971, donated in 1994 by Mr. Antonio Cusano, is to be managed in accordance with the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act. The funds are to be used for designing and constructing an environmental education center and refuge headquarters at the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge at Tinicum, with the facility to be donated to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service upon completion. Antonio Cusano of Crum Lynne, Pennsylvania donated approximately $2,473,971 in 1994 for an environmental education center and refuge headquarters at the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge at Tinicum. All proceeds derived from the donation are included in the period since the donation was made.
